content.text: Define gravitational potential at a point
It takes TESS 13.7 days to orbit the Earth
Show that the radius of orbit of TESS is \(2.4 \times 10^{8} \text{m}\)
Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy between TESS in orbit and TESS on a launch pad on the surface of the Earth
change in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J
Use the information in (b)(i) to calculate the ratio:
gravitational field strength on surface of Earth
gravitational field strength at location of TESS in orbit
TESS is a satellite of mass \(360\mathrm{kg}\) in a circular orbit about the Earth as shown in Fig. 1.1
The radius of the Earth is \(6.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) and the mass of the Earth, considered to be a point mass at its centre, is \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\)
Show that the temperature \(T\) of the gas is approximately \(300 \text{K}\)
The temperature of the gas is increased to \(350 \text{K}\) at constant volume. The specific heat capacity of the gas for this change is \(0.66 \text{J} \text{kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\)
Calculate the energy supplied to the gas by heating
energy =   .........  J
Explain how movement of the gas molecules causes pressure in the container
The temperature of a gas depends on the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of its molecules
Calculate the ratio:
r.m.s. speed of gas molecules at \(350 \text{K}\)
r.m.s. speed of gas molecules at \(300 \text{K}\)
A large container of volume \(85 \text{m}^3\) is filled with \(110 \text{kg}\) of an ideal gas. The pressure of the gas is \(1.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) at temperature \(T\)
The mass of \(1.0 \text{mol}\) of the gas is \(32 \text{g}\)
State the amplitude \(x_{\mathrm{o}}\) of the oscillations
Calculate the period \(T\) of the oscillations
On Fig. 3.1, label with a P a point where the body has **maximum** potential energy.
A body undergoes simple harmonic motion
The variation with displacement \(x\) of its velocity \(v\) is shown in Fig. 3.1
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
The switch is now closed. Explain why the oscillations of the magnet are damped
A bar magnet is suspended from the free end of a spring, as shown in Fig. 3.2
One pole of the magnet is situated in a coil of wire. The coil is connected in series with a switch and a resistor. The switch is open
The magnet is displaced vertically and then released. The magnet oscillates with simple harmonic motion
Explain why ultrasound used in medical diagnosis is emitted in pulses
Explain the principles of the **detection** of ultrasound waves used in medical diagnosis
The specific acoustic impedances of two media are \(Z_{1}\) and \(Z_{2}\). The intensity reflection coefficient \(\alpha\) for the boundary of these two media is given by:
Calculate, to three significant figures, the fraction of the ultrasound intensity that is reflected at a boundary between air and soft tissue
Use your value in **(b)**(i) to explain why gel is applied to the surface of the skin during an ultrasound scan
The specific acoustic impedances \(\mathbf{Z}\) of some media are given in Table 4.1
State two advantages of the transmission of data in digital form, rather than analogue form
A signal in an optic fibre is carried by an electromagnetic wave of frequency \(1.36 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\). The speed of the wave in the fibre is \(2.07 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{-1}\)
For this electromagnetic wave, determine the ratio:
The attenuation per unit length of the signal in the fibre is \(0.40 \text{dB} \text{km}^{-1}\). The input power is \(1.5 \text{mW}\) and the output power is \(0.060 \text{mW}\)
Calculate the length of the fibre
length =   .........  km
Optic fibres are used for the transmission of data
State the radius of the two spheres
The charge on sphere A is \(3.6 \times 10^{- 9} \text{C}\). Determine the charge \(Q_{\text{B}}\) on sphere B
Assume that spheres A and B can be treated as point charges at their centres
Explain your working
Sphere B is removed
Use information from **(b)** to determine the electric potential on the surface of sphere A
electric potential =   .........  V
Calculate the capacitance of sphere A
capacitance =   .........  F
Two positively charged identical metal spheres A and B have their centres separated by a distance of \(24 \text{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 6.1
The variation with distance \(x\) from the centre of A of the electric field strength \(E\) due to the two spheres, along the line joining their centres, is represented in Fig. 6.2
On Fig. 7.1, sketch the temperature characteristic of a negative temperature coefficient (n.t.c.) thermistor. Label the axes with quantity and unit
An n.t.c. thermistor and a resistor are connected as shown in Fig. 7.2
The temperature of the thermistor is increased
State and explain the change, if any, to the reading on the voltmeter
The variation with the fractional change in length \(\Delta x / x\) of the fractional change in resistance \(\Delta R / R\) for a strain gauge is shown in Fig. 7.3
The unstrained resistance of the gauge is \(120\Omega\). Calculate the new resistance of the gauge when it is extended to a strain of 0.020
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
Explain what is meant by a magnetic field

The apparatus shown in Fig. 8.1 is used in an experiment to find the magnetic flux density \(B\) between the poles of a horseshoe magnet. Assume the magnetic field is uniform between the poles of the magnet and zero elsewhere

The rigid metal rod of length \(300\mathrm{mm}\) is fixed in position perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic field. The poles of the magnet are both \(45\mathrm{mm}\) long. There is a current in the rod that causes a force on the rod. The balance is used to determine the magnitude of the force
The variation with current \(I\) of the force \(F\) on the rod is shown in Fig. 8.2
Explain why the electrons follow a circular path when inside the region of the magnetic field
State the measurements needed in order to determine the charge to mass ratio, \(e / m_{\mathrm{e}}\), of an electron

In a different experiment, electrons are accelerated through a potential difference and then enter a region of magnetic field. The magnetic field is into the plane of the paper and is perpendicular to the direction of travel of the electrons, as illustrated in Fig. 8.3
the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) voltage, \(V_{\mathrm{r.m.s.}}\)
the period \(T\)
The output of a power supply is represented by:
where \(V\) is the potential difference in volts and \(t\) is the time in seconds
Determine, for the output of the supply:
The variations with time \(t\) of the output potential difference \(V\) from two different power supplies are shown in Fig. 9.1 and Fig. 9.2
Fig. 9.2
The graphs are drawn to the same scale
State and explain whether the same power would be dissipated in a \(1.0 \Omega\) resistor connected to each power supply
The power supply in **(a)** is connected to a transformer. The input power to the transformer is \(80 \text{W}\)
The secondary coil is connected to a resistor. The r.m.s. voltage across the resistor is \(120 \text{V}\). The r.m.s. current in the secondary coil is \(0.64 \text{A}\)
Calculate the efficiency of the transformer
efficiency =   .........
State **one** reason why the transformer is not \(100\%\) efficient
By reference to the photoelectric effect, explain what is meant by work function energy
Determine the work function energy in J of the metal used in the experiment
work function energy =   .........  J
The work function energy in eV for some metals is given in Table 10.1
Determine the metal used in the experiment. Show your working
In an experiment, electromagnetic radiation of frequency \(f\) is incident on a metal surface
The results in Fig. 10.1 show the variation with frequency \(f\) of the maximum kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) of electrons emitted from the surface
the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted electrons
the rate of emission of photoelectrons
The intensity of the electromagnetic radiation for one particular frequency in **(b)** is increased
State and explain the change, if any, in:
Calculate the maximum possible frequency of the emitted X-ray photons
frequency =   .........  \(Hz\)
Explain why an aluminium filter may be placed in the X-ray beam when producing an X-ray image of a patient
A beam of these X-rays is incident on a person
Calculate the percentage of the intensity of the X-ray beam that has been absorbed after passing through \(0.80 \text{cm}\) of blood
percentage of intensity absorbed =   .........  %
In an X-ray image, white regions show greater absorption of X-rays than dark regions
State and explain the difference between the X-ray image of bone compared to that of muscle
The linear attenuation (absorption) coefficients \(\mu\) for X-rays in bone, blood and muscle are given in Table 11.1
Electrons are accelerated through a potential difference of \(100\mathrm{kV}.\) They are then incident on a metal target, they decelerate, and X-ray photons are emitted
Explain what is meant by the binding energy of a nucleus
Determine the values of \(x\) and \(y\)
x =
y =
State the name of this type of nuclear reaction
Compare the binding energy per nucleon of uranium-235 with the binding energy per nucleon of caesium-144
The following nuclear reaction takes place:
Yttrium-90 decays into zirconium-90, a stable isotope
A sample initially consists of pure yttrium-90
Calculate the time, in days, when the ratio of the number of yttrium-90 nuclei to the number of zirconium-90 nuclei would be 2.0
The half-life of yttrium-90 is 2.7 days
time =   .........  days
